feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A holiday is a temporal and cultural construct, not a physical object.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — While culturally constructed, it is not a manufactured or synthetic entity.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It has no biological properties.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — The date or form may vary across calendars or traditions.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — A holiday does not form a physical or functional structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Though associated events may be perceivable, the holiday itself is not inherently sensory.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It does not exist as a tangible substance.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It actively drives behavior and societal coordination.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Religious holidays are intentionally created to fulfill spiritual, commemorative, or ritual purposes.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not produce a measurable or signal-based output.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It is not a processing system.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — While it may influence mood or behavior, this is not its structural identity.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is not an interface or agent.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Religious holidays are intrinsic components of religious systems and calendars.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It requires observance and social structures to exist.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — The religion can exist without a specific holiday, though holidays reinforce system structure.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Religious holidays represent key doctrines, historical events, or beliefs (e.g., resurrection, liberation, revelation).
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — It is not itself a channel of communication.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — It is observed via rules, but the concept itself is not inherently logical.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — It is not composed of modular sub-parts in a structural way.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Holidays guide ritual behavior, abstention, celebration, or acts of devotion.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — It does not reference its own concept or model abstraction.
feedback.Temporal: Included — A holiday is, by definition, a temporally anchored occasion.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — It is tightly bound to its contextual tradition.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Holidays are created and maintained by cultural and religious traditions.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — A religious body or tradition defines the holiday.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — Observance often expresses group identity and affiliation.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Rituals, calendars, and authorities govern the holiday.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — It is passed down through generations and formal education.
feedback.Visible: Included — Celebrations are observable in public or ritual spaces.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Its meaning depends entirely on cultural and religious context.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Major religious holidays are broadly recognized within or across cultures.

encoding_notes: This revision addresses prior conceptual underrepresentation by incorporating traits that are essential to the identity of a religious holiday. It now reflects its symbolic nature, temporality, and its embeddedness within larger religious systems. The corrected code '00848AFF' now faithfully matches the selected traits.
